Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: The school reports that the child was caught bullying a classmate, and the parent needs to respond
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A production outage traces back to a defect in their code and customers cannot access the service
Story: My phone buzzes with two notifications at once. The first is an email from my child’s school: my son was caught bullying a classmate, and the principal wants to meet with me today. The second is a Slack message from my manager—our production system is down, and the outage is traced to a bug in my code. Customers are locked out, and the team is scrambling for a fix. I stare at my screen, heart pounding. My son needs me to show up, to listen, to help him understand the gravity of his actions. But my team is counting on me too; the company’s reputation and our users’ trust are on the line. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait. My mind races, torn between the urgent needs of my child and the crisis at work, knowing that whatever I choose, something important will be left behind.
